keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including traditional signs like unusual animal behavior, loud sounds, and signal fires, plays a vital role in early warning for glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs) in northern Pakistan.
Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa continue to rely on human-based early warning systems due to frequent failures and lack of trust in official technology.
Despite a $37 million GLOF-II project and government spending, real-time integration between local human sensors and official rescue teams remains absent, leading to community distrust.
A 2023 World Bank report shows Pakistan's temperature has risen twice as fast as the global average, increasing climate vulnerability and the frequency of disasters.

When local shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain alert communities using traditional signals (e.g., gunfire, fire), lives are saved—demonstrating the efficacy and cultural embeddedness of Indigenous knowledge.
The lack of trust in government systems has led to criticism from local activists and opposition leaders, with demands for investigations into EWS failures.
The Pakistani government has recognized the value of community-based resilience by awarding shepherds $28,000 each for saving lives, acknowledging their role in disaster response.
Global challenges cited by the UNDP—such as financial constraints, data gaps, communication barriers, and weak institutional capacity—apply to Pakistan’s early warning system development.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, especially in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing unusual animal behavior, hearing roaring sounds, or using gunfire and fires as warning signals—is proving more effective than government-installed early warning systems in preventing loss of life during glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite significant investment, including a $37 million GLOF-II project, many systems remain non-operational, and communities lack trust in the technology due to frequent failures and lack of follow-up. In contrast, local shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain have repeatedly saved lives by using time-tested, community-based warning methods. The article underscores a broader global challenge: even with technological infrastructure, early warning systems fail without community trust, local engagement, and cultural relevance. As climate change accelerates glacier melt and flood risks, Pakistan’s reliance on Indigenous knowledge highlights both a resilience strategy and a systemic gap in climate adaptation policy.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
